snippet.title: Crucial to follow the rules to avoid 'the bends'
snippet.content: MILLIONS of recreational dives are conducted around the world every year without incident. It is a very safe sport but there are inherent risks. Occasionally a diver for no apparent reason will suffer from decompression sickness, which is sometimes called the bends. All divers receive basic training in how to avoid the bends. This includes not diving too deep, and not exceeding safe underwater time limits. Care should be taken when more than two dives a day are planned. Divers generally are knowledgeable with the signs and symptoms of a severe case of the bends. These include joint pain which requires treatment in a recompression chamber. The nearest chamber to the Sunshine Coast is the Royal Brisbane Hospital. A big mystery which still baffles doctors specialising in hyperbaric medicine is why one diver becomes prone to decompression sickness while his diving buddy who performed exactly the same dive avoids any signs of symptoms or signs. All dive charter boats carry medical oxygen in the unlikely event a diver may require it.
